primitive_props.translation: The Ottoman Empire had a millet system.
primitive_props.evidence: “...under the Ottoman Empire's millet system...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic historical assertion about existence of an institution; no logical connectives.

primitive_props.translation: Under the Ottoman millet system, religion was the defining characteristic of national groups (milletler).
primitive_props.evidence: “...religion was the defining characteristic of national groups (milletler) ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Single predication about what defined national groups under the system.

primitive_props.translation: The term “Rumlar” (exonym “Greeks”) comes from the name “Rhomaioi”.
primitive_props.evidence: “...the exonym ‘Greeks’ (Rumlar from the name Rhomaioi) ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic etymological claim; no internal conjunction/disjunction.

primitive_props.translation: The Ottomans applied the exonym “Greeks” (Rumlar) to members of the Orthodox Church.
primitive_props.evidence: “...was applied by the Ottomans to all members of the Orthodox Church ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic claim about an Ottoman naming practice directed at a target group.

primitive_props.translation: The Ottomans applied the exonym “Greeks” (Rumlar) to Orthodox Church members who spoke Greek.
primitive_props.evidence: “...applied ... to all members of the Orthodox Church, regardless of their language ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic specialization for Greek-speaking Orthodox members (used to model ‘regardless of language’ without connectives).

primitive_props.translation: The Ottomans applied the exonym “Greeks” (Rumlar) to Orthodox Church members who did not speak Greek.
primitive_props.evidence: “...applied ... to all members of the Orthodox Church, regardless of their language ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic specialization for non-Greek-speaking Orthodox members (used to model ‘regardless of language’).

primitive_props.translation: The Ottomans applied the exonym “Greeks” (Rumlar) to Orthodox Church members regardless of ethnic origin.
primitive_props.evidence: “...regardless of their ... ethnic origin.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic statement capturing ethnic-origin-independence as a single claim.

primitive_props.translation: Greek speakers called themselves Romioi.
primitive_props.evidence: “The Greek speakers were the only ethnic group to actually call themselves Romioi ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic self-identification claim (no connectives).

primitive_props.translation: Non-Greek-speaking ethnic groups called themselves Romioi.
primitive_props.evidence: “The Greek speakers were the only ethnic group to actually call themselves Romioi ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic alternative used to encode the ‘only’ condition via constraints.

primitive_props.translation: Educated Greek speakers considered their ethnicity (genos) to be Hellenic.
primitive_props.evidence: “...and, at least those educated, considered their ethnicity (genos) to be Hellenic.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic belief/identity attribution about a specified subgroup (educated Greek speakers).

primitive_props.translation: In the Ottoman millet system, Christians had second-class status.
primitive_props.evidence: “...the second-class status of Christians inherent in the Ottoman millet system ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic status assignment to Christians under the system.

primitive_props.translation: In the Ottoman millet system, Muslims were awarded senior status.
primitive_props.evidence: “...according to which Muslims were explicitly awarded senior status ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic status assignment to Muslims under the system.

primitive_props.translation: In the Ottoman millet system, Muslims received preferential treatment.
primitive_props.evidence: “...and preferential treatment.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic treatment claim; no logical operators.

primitive_props.translation: Many Greeks escaped the second-class status of Christians inherent in the Ottoman millet system.
primitive_props.evidence: “There were, however, many Greeks who escaped the second-class status of Christians ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic historical claim about a group’s outcome (escape).

primitive_props.translation: The Greeks who escaped emigrated to the Russian Empire.
primitive_props.evidence: “These Greeks either emigrated ... to ... the Russian Empire ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic action claim (emigration) about the referenced group.

primitive_props.translation: The Greeks who escaped converted to Islam.
primitive_props.evidence: “...or simply converted to Islam ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic action claim (conversion) about the referenced group.

primitive_props.translation: The Russian Empire was a protector of Greek Orthodox people.
primitive_props.evidence: “...their fellow Greek Orthodox protector, the Russian Empire ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic role/relationship claim about the Russian Empire.

primitive_props.translation: The Greeks who escaped were Christians.
primitive_props.evidence: “...Greeks who escaped the second-class status of Christians ... These Greeks ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic group-membership/status attribution implied by ‘escaped the ... status of Christians’.

primitive_props.translation: The Greeks who escaped became Muslims.
primitive_props.evidence: “...converted to Islam ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic post-conversion religious-status claim (used for semantic linking).

primitive_props.translation: Some Greeks converted to Islam superficially.
primitive_props.evidence: “...often only very superficially ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic conversion-quality claim; hedge handled via soft constraints rather than in the proposition.

primitive_props.translation: Some Greeks who converted to Islam remained crypto-Christian.
primitive_props.evidence: “...whilst remaining crypto-Christian.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic claim about continued (hidden) Christianity; hedge handled via soft constraints.

primitive_props.translation: There were notable large-scale conversions to Turkish Islam among those today defined as Greek Muslims.
primitive_props.evidence: “The most notable examples of large-scale conversion to Turkish Islam among those today defined as Greek Muslims ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic existence claim about a phenomenon (large-scale conversion) in a described population.

primitive_props.translation: Notable large-scale conversion to Turkish Islam among Greek Muslims occurred in Crete.
primitive_props.evidence: “...were to be found in Crete (Cretan Turks) ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic location claim for one cited example.

primitive_props.translation: Notable large-scale conversion to Turkish Islam among Greek Muslims occurred in Greek Macedonia.
primitive_props.evidence: “...Greek Macedonia (for example among the Vallahades of western Macedonia) ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic location claim for one cited example.

primitive_props.translation: Notable large-scale conversion to Turkish Islam among Greek Muslims occurred among Pontic Greeks in the Pontic Alps and Armenian Highlands.
primitive_props.evidence: “...among Pontic Greeks in the Pontic Alps and Armenian Highlands.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic location/group claim for one cited example.

primitive_props.translation: Devshirme recruits had to convert to Islam as a matter of course.
primitive_props.evidence: “...excluding those who had to convert as a matter of course on being recruited through the devshirme ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic policy/requirement claim about a specific group (devshirme recruits).

primitive_props.translation: The text’s ‘most notable examples’ of large-scale conversion include devshirme recruits.
primitive_props.evidence: “...excluding those who had to convert ... through the devshirme ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic inclusion claim introduced to encode the explicit exclusion as a hard negation.

primitive_props.translation: Several Ottoman sultans and princes were of part Greek origin.
primitive_props.evidence: “Several Ottoman sultans and princes were also of part Greek origin ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic demographic/ancestry claim; no connectives.

primitive_props.translation: The mothers of those part-Greek-origin sultans and princes were Greek concubines.
primitive_props.evidence: “...with mothers who were either Greek concubines ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic claim about one possible maternal category (kept separate for later disjunction constraint).

primitive_props.translation: The mothers of those part-Greek-origin sultans and princes were princesses from Byzantine noble families.
primitive_props.evidence: “...or princesses from Byzantine noble families ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic claim about the other possible maternal category.

primitive_props.translation: Selim the Grim was an Ottoman sultan.
primitive_props.evidence: “...one famous example being sultan Selim the Grim ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic role identity (Selim is a sultan).

primitive_props.translation: Gülbahar Hatun was Selim the Grim’s mother.
primitive_props.evidence: “...whose mother Gülbahar Hatun ...”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic parentage claim.

primitive_props.translation: Gülbahar Hatun was a Pontic Greek.
primitive_props.evidence: “...Gülbahar Hatun was a Pontic Greek.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic ethnic-origin claim.

primitive_props.translation: Gülbahar Hatun was Greek.
primitive_props.evidence: Implied by: “...was a Pontic Greek.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic superclass membership (Pontic Greek entails Greek); used for semantic constraints.

primitive_props.translation: Selim the Grim was of part Greek origin.
primitive_props.evidence: “...one famous example being sultan Selim the Grim, whose mother ... was a Pontic Greek.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic ancestry claim inferred directly from the provided example sentence structure.

hard_constraints.translation: The Ottoman Empire had a millet system.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...Ottoman Empire's millet system...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Directly asserted background fact.

hard_constraints.translation: Religion defined national groups under the millet system.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...religion was the defining characteristic...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Directly asserted as a defining feature.

hard_constraints.translation: “Rumlar” derives from “Rhomaioi”.
hard_constraints.evidence: “(Rumlar from the name Rhomaioi)”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Direct etymological assertion.

hard_constraints.translation: Ottomans applied the exonym “Greeks” to Orthodox Church members.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...applied by the Ottomans to all members of the Orthodox Church...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Directly stated naming practice.

hard_constraints.translation: Applying “Rumlar” to Orthodox members held independent of language and ethnic origin.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...to all members ... regardless of their language or ethnic origin.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Semantic unpacking of “all members ... regardless of ...” into component conditions; treated as definitional of the described practice.

hard_constraints.translation: Greek speakers called themselves Romioi.
hard_constraints.evidence: “The Greek speakers were the only ethnic group to actually call themselves Romioi ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Directly asserted.

hard_constraints.translation: No non-Greek-speaking ethnic groups called themselves Romioi (in the sense intended by the text’s ‘only’).
hard_constraints.evidence: “...were the only ethnic group to actually call themselves Romioi ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: ‘Only’ creates an exclusivity condition: if Greek speakers are the only ethnic group to do so, then non-Greek(-speaking) ethnic groups did not.

hard_constraints.translation: Educated Greek speakers considered their ethnicity Hellenic.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...at least those educated, considered their ethnicity (genos) to be Hellenic.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Directly asserted about a specific subgroup.

hard_constraints.translation: Christians had second-class status in the millet system.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...second-class status of Christians inherent in the Ottoman millet system...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Directly asserted structural condition.

hard_constraints.translation: Muslims were awarded senior status in the millet system.
hard_constraints.evidence: “Muslims were explicitly awarded senior status ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Directly asserted structural condition.

hard_constraints.translation: Muslims received preferential treatment in the millet system.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...and preferential treatment.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Directly asserted structural condition.

hard_constraints.translation: If Muslims have senior status, then Muslims receive preferential treatment.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...awarded senior status and preferential treatment.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: The text pairs senior status with preferential treatment as part of the same explicit award; ‘senior status’ semantically entails preferential treatment in this described policy context.

hard_constraints.translation: Many Greeks escaped the second-class status of Christians.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...many Greeks who escaped the second-class status of Christians ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Directly asserted.

hard_constraints.translation: The Greeks who escaped were Christians (as they are described as escaping Christians’ second-class status).
hard_constraints.evidence: “...escaped the second-class status of Christians ... These Greeks ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Semantic link: escaping the second-class status of Christians presupposes being within the category subjected to that status.

hard_constraints.translation: The Greeks who escaped either emigrated to the Russian Empire or converted to Islam.
hard_constraints.evidence: “These Greeks either emigrated ... or simply converted to Islam ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Direct ‘either ... or ...’ requirement (at least one route is described for the group).

hard_constraints.translation: If those (contextual) Greeks emigrated or converted (as described), then they are among the Greeks who escaped the second-class status.
hard_constraints.evidence: “These Greeks either emigrated ... or ... converted ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Textual anaphora: “These Greeks” refers to the previously mentioned Greeks who escaped; the actions are presented as the way they escaped.

hard_constraints.translation: The Russian Empire was a protector of Greek Orthodox people.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...their fellow Greek Orthodox protector, the Russian Empire ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Directly asserted.

hard_constraints.translation: If the Greeks converted to Islam, then they became Muslims.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...converted to Islam ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Common-sense semantic entailment of ‘convert to Islam’.

hard_constraints.translation: There were notable large-scale conversions to Turkish Islam among those today defined as Greek Muslims.
hard_constraints.evidence: “The most notable examples of large-scale conversion to Turkish Islam among those today defined as Greek Muslims ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Directly asserted existence of such examples.

hard_constraints.translation: Notable large-scale conversions were found in Crete, Greek Macedonia, and among Pontic Greeks (Pontic Alps/Armenian Highlands).
hard_constraints.evidence: “...to be found in Crete ... Greek Macedonia ... and among Pontic Greeks ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: These locations/groups are explicitly listed as where the most notable examples were found.

hard_constraints.translation: Devshirme recruits had to convert to Islam as a matter of course.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...had to convert as a matter of course on being recruited through the devshirme ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Directly asserted exception category.

hard_constraints.translation: The ‘most notable examples’ described do not include devshirme recruits.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...excluding those who had to convert ... through the devshirme ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: ‘Excluding’ is an explicit hard exclusion.

hard_constraints.translation: Several Ottoman sultans and princes were of part Greek origin.
hard_constraints.evidence: “Several Ottoman sultans and princes were also of part Greek origin ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Directly asserted.

hard_constraints.translation: Their mothers were either Greek concubines or Byzantine-noble princesses.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...with mothers who were either Greek concubines or princesses from Byzantine noble families ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Directly stated disjunctive condition tied to the described set of sultans/princes.

hard_constraints.translation: Selim the Grim was a sultan; Gülbahar Hatun was his mother; she was a Pontic Greek.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...sultan Selim the Grim, whose mother Gülbahar Hatun was a Pontic Greek.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: All three are explicitly asserted in the example sentence.

hard_constraints.translation: If Gülbahar Hatun was Pontic Greek, then she was Greek.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...was a Pontic Greek.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Common-sense taxonomic entailment: Pontic Greek is a kind of Greek.

hard_constraints.translation: If Selim’s mother was Greek, then Selim was of part Greek origin.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...one famous example being ... Selim ... whose mother ... was a Pontic Greek.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Common-sense ancestry inference: having a Greek mother entails part Greek origin.

hard_constraints.translation: Selim the Grim was of part Greek origin.
hard_constraints.evidence: “...one famous example being sultan Selim the Grim, whose mother ... was a Pontic Greek.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Text presents Selim explicitly as a famous example of part Greek origin; treated as asserted conclusion of the example.

soft_constraints.translation: If the Greeks who escaped converted to Islam, then the conversion was superficial.
soft_constraints.reasoning: The hedge word “often” indicates this is not guaranteed for all such conversions, so it is defeasible.

soft_constraints.translation: If the Greeks who escaped converted to Islam, then they remained crypto-Christian.
soft_constraints.evidence: “...often only very superficially and whilst remaining crypto-Christian.”
soft_constraints.reasoning: The hedge word “often” makes this a non-universal tendency rather than a strict rule.

soft_constraints.translation: The Greeks who escaped did not both emigrate to the Russian Empire and convert to Islam.
soft_constraints.evidence: Common-sense reading of “either emigrated ... or ... converted ...”.
soft_constraints.reasoning: Natural-language “either/or” often implies exclusivity, but it is not strictly forced (someone could convert and later emigrate), so this is treated as soft.
